utterances: Skype lets you make telephone and video calls over the Internet.
About 125 million people use the company's mostly free services every month.
Now, the company is about to hold an IPO - or initial public offering - and sell some stock to the public.
Skype filed documents saying it wants to sell $100 million worth of shares that would be traded on the NASDAQ exchange.
Attorney Joe Bartlett, an expert in these kinds of deals, suggests the company's rationale for the IPO.
The hope is that they can use the $100 million to create a $5 billion company.
That's what IPOs are all about.
Skype posted a modest profit this year, but it's had trouble making money.
eBay, which bought the company in 2005 and sold most of it off last year, can attest to that.

Getting people to pay for services that had been offered for free remains a challenge, so analysts expect the company to expand into more video conferencing, mobile use,and document storage and sharing.
But Skype will likely face competition from the likes of Google and Microsoft.
Still, Wharton professor David Hsu suggests the offering is an encouraging sign.
Relative to the last two years or so in which the IPO markets have been stone cold, things are starting to pick up a bit.
He adds: We don't know how successful this - or a handful of other -recently announced IPOs will be, but at least companies are again considering the IPO option.
All summer long, we're asking actors, writers and directors about the movies that they never get tired of watching, including this one from one of the stars of the film ""People Like Us.
The movie I've seen a million times and can't get enough of is ""Pulp Fiction,"" written and directed by Quentin Tarantino.
It stars John Travolta, Sam Jackson and a bevy of other amazing people, including Bruce Willis.
(as Brett) We got into this thing with the best intentions, really.
JACKSON: (as Jules Winnfield) Oh, I'm sorry.
Pulp Fiction"" is a series of vignettes that tell multiple interacting stories in a completely nonlinear fashion...
(as Jules Winnfield) What country are you from?
(as Jules Winnfield) What ain't no country I ever heard of.
And what's so great about it is every character jumps off the screen.
(as Vincent Vega) I heard you did a pilot.
(as Mia Wallace) It was a show about a team of female secret agents called ""Fox Force Five.
(as Mia Wallace) ""Fox Force Five."" Fox, as in we're a bunch of foxy chicks, force as in we're a force to be reckoned with and five as in there's one, two, three, four, five of us.
One of my favorite moments in the movie involved a really small character played by Eric Stoltz.
He's talking to John Travolta who's on the phone and bringing Uma Thurman to his house...
...to be shot in the chest with adrenaline after she's OD'd and he says, are you calling me from a cell phone?
(as Lance) Are you talking to me on a cellular phone?
And then says, I don't know you.
And I don't know why, but it's such an honest moment to me that Eric Stoltz delivered.
I just love that moment in the movie.
Quentin has such a specific voice in the movie, and the language that he uses is incredible and completely melodic, and as an actor, that's the kind of language that we all want to speak.
(as Jules Winnfield) And I will strike down upon thee with great vengeance and furious anger those who attempt to poison and destroy my brother.
Sam Jackson has some of the greatest lines.
(as Jules Winnfield) And you will know my name is the Lord.
